title: Really hate how riot's design has actively discriminated against passive methodical play styles
body:
Because you want to know what i think of when i think of a strategy game?

Probably not, but I can ensure you that no one is looking for spastic quarter second decision making mixed in with button mashing and raw power advantage.

Like how they removed dodge back in what was it, season 1? And crit is still here in season 7 soon to be probably season 8 as well.

No they are not. They like *a bit* of randomness to make trades less predictable. Because if you can exactly predict the end of a trade (and with a point-and-click, un-dodgeable auto-attack, you do can), the one that would lose the trade will just refuse trading at all, and you get a boring, un-interactive game.

There have been various answers on Fearless and Ghostcrawler Tumblrs where they explained that.

The problem I have with that philosophy is it assumes that abilities don't get to change the outcome. It also assumes the other guy won't get Crits to just kill you even faster (and being ahead, they can afford more Crit Chance). Yeah, there's a tiny bit of uncertainty it adds early, but if all you're looking for is a tiny bit of uncertainty in autos why not just have Crit Chance be a base stat that scales with levels instead of an item stat?

If Crit exists primarily to sway the right click vs right click matchup, why don't they change how that matchup works? Change auto attacks to behave more like the Culling against champions, instead of being auto locked projectiles.

Don't ask me. I'm not arguing for or against, I'm just repeating known facts and reasoning that Riot has told us, but beyond that, your guess is just as good as mine.

Still, my initial point in reply to RocketRelm still stands: Riot is NOT working on phasing out Crit chance at the moment.

I have to agree with this. Everyone but mages and assassins needs toning down.

Mages and assassins too, but less than the rest. It's not ok for a Syndra to kill a carry just with ult. I understand that by nerfing everyone's damage, champions that rely on burst the most are hit the most, and sustain monsters thrive. If riot actually were to do this, which I seriously doubt they would, they'd need to make a balance "pass" to compensate for these and more factors. For starters, burst reliant champions should generally be nerfed less. Secondly, utility buffs could help phase out some of the burden of not being able to 1 shot carries anymore. Or small kit changes to make it so even though you are fully burst focused, there's more skill and counterplay to it.

Regardless, sustain would have to be hit too, so if you're a burst mage in this hypothetical new league and you burst the enemy adc from 100 to 20, he's not just going to recover all his health in 3 basics, and so he'll be in big danger if he wants to continue fighting, but at least the choice is there. This means burst isn't useless against adcs if it fails to kill. Ofc sustain shouldn't be gutted, though. Opting for a more lifesteal focused build should be an option, just not one that dominates the others and instead is a meaningful choice you have to make.

In this ideal League of mine, adcs wouldn't be so opressive that you'd have to 1 shot them at the start of the fight to have a chance, and so assassins would generally still function mostly the same except instead of going in when the target is full hp they'd go in after the target has been damaged enough if they want to instaburst, or if the target is out of position and/or the rest of the enemy team is busy, they'd go in earlier and they wouldn't have the problem of the adc being left at 10% hp and them being 2 shot while the adc recovers half his health.

To finish off, I think it'd be cool to have slowly ramping damage items/abilities for champions that want more dps at the cost of burst. Sort of like the concept with guinsoo's rageblade but different, and an actual item that more than a couple of champions would want to build.

Yes when you start trying to manage hundreds of units, for the sake of micro you want a high APM, but that's nothing to do with the actual strategy of the game.

League does have a bunch of mind games, and regarding your reply to Sp33d Zer0, I do agree the damage right now is too high. However, it's not like there isn't strategic thinking to it. It's more like as if you're playing starcraft and your macro is terrible so no matter the strategy you come up with you're still going to lose, and deserve to lose.

For example, you don't need great reaction time if your damage foresight, positioning and understanding of zones and jungler influence are great. Instead of having to react to things you can already know when they're coming out if you understand how your enemy thinks, or not get in the situation if you don't. Regardless, while there is still a lot of strategy and thought that can go into the game, there's still a lot of things I dislike about it, and lack of strategic venues happens to be one of them, despite what I just said.

There is both involved, and I can say this as a top main, and I'm sure all other lanes have it in different forms. 

Shen for instance, the micro play comes from aiming the taunt, aiming the collision for the empowered hits (in this case usually not relevant because you will almost always get it if done while taunting), then timing the W to block some counter trades, or using it reactively against bullies like Renekton. The better you are at micro, the more damage you can pull off in a combo, the higher the chances you can dodge skillshots reactively and overall, get a better result in a particular skirmish/objective/siege/lane trade. 

Macro play would be reading the enemy cooldowns, enemy jungler location, the enemy mid laner location, my laner's ward locations and timer, and as a Shen thing, possible interventions with R, and after considering all of these, choosing the best course of action. This could be picking a good fight, going for an objective or even retreating.

However, neither of these will work without each other. You can be a Vayne mechanics god but if you don't read the map and get caught out, no amount of micro is going to get you out of the cc and nukes of 5 enemies surrounding you. This is how some scripters still end up feeding. But yet, if you know all the ins and outs of the map, and you pick a good fight to engage in... if you can't kite for shit, the diver is going to kill you. The Kog maw video by Rubick is a different story, I for one cannot even comprehend how that it is even possible for an ADC to facetank. I have never seen something like that in my low level of play. Kiting 10/10 indeed.

Both macro and micro play are important in this game, you cannot solely rely on one to win games. You don't need to be extremely good at both, but you just cannot have one without the other.
League isn't an RTS.
What exactly is the counter to a passive, methodical playstyle? Is it "Hope they fuck up and you can kill them"? You've now identified why such playstyles are a problem.

Focused and calculated aggression resulting in a tactical advantage.

This advantage is a key and unlocks the win door if you got enough of them.

Right now you get one key, maybe a second one, and open the door already.

There's a happy medium between making one mistake and being punished incredibly hard for it (OP's complaint), and requiring a myriad of "keys" just to punish someone at all. Accruing all of those small advantages, or "keys", in lane is ok for the most part. Cs'ing better than your laner, forcing them into undesirable trades, proper warding, etc. One small mistake shouldn't cost you the lane. However the farther into the game you go, the more punishing your mistakes should be.

Well obviously you shouldn't need dozens of keys.

You shouldn't lose or win based on a single mistake.

Let's call a game of league war. You need to win several battles to win the war and the closer you get to the enemy capital city the more punishing his losses become.

And this is what league also should look like. If a small mistake in midgame can make the enemy power go from modern day Austria to WW2 Soviet Union and advancing halfway to your capital city it is too much gain.

You should win games by winning small battles like outfarming your opponent, aquiring buffs, killing towers, etc. Win step by step instead of winning with huge leaps.

I hope that makes sense.

Paasive-methodical playstyles only work when you can trust your teammates to not feed before the 15 minute mark. Only in high elo does this happen, which is why Riot makes effort to speed games up, in order to make pros more exciting to watch early-mid game.

In lower elos, everyone else is expected to do everything quicky. Foresight and planning takes a back seat to twitch mechanics and individual carry potential.

It's unfortunate, but that's just the result of balancing solely around pro play. Riot can't slow things down for everyone without making pros less exciting to watch, which in turn warps the game for everyone in lower elos. It's a vicious cycle that can't be stopped without taking some real risks. I dont expect it to occur any time soon.

There's a difference between passive and safe.

Passive meaning you can look to get a lead without fighting and/or trading to near death with the enemy champion constantly.
Safe meaning you look to only make decisions that you can ensure will work out in your favor. 

These two things can overlap, but they're not the same thing.

LCS proves that this is indeed a strategy game. You may not think it because you or your peers don't enlist strategy to win. The entire game set-up is strategy (Tank/Fighter Top, Tank/Fighter/Assassin Jg, Mage/Assassin Mid, Marksman Bot, Support Bot). Warding, lane swaps, pushing for objectives, wave management, synergy, etc. The list goes on. This game is full of strategy and the META is strategic picking selection of champions that are better performing than others in the state of the game.
